title: IonQ Stock in Freefall. Here's Why.

transcript.text:
When my favorite stock goes up, it's because 
of my Nostradamus-like investing acumen,

when my favorite stock falls, it's the market's 
fault. Well, IonQ has been falling a lot lately,

which has some investors asking why. The answer 
is quite simple. It's the market. I'm joking,

of course. It's because the value of the business 
doesn't match the current stock price. Today,

we're going to look at everything Ionq has been up 
to. And throughout this, you'll learn a lot about

investing in quantum computing. I'll also answer 
one question that you all haven't stopped asking.

Why quantum computing? Well, quantum computers can 
solve problems that classical computers can't. So,

here's a simple example. Your typical UPS driver, 
the UPS man, makes an average of 135 deliveries

daily. The number of possible routes they could 
take is so large that you'd have to describe

it with 227 digits. It would take a classical 
computer longer than the age of the universe to

calculate the true optimal route for a driver. 
What they call the traveling salesman problem.

UPS would need to do this for more than 66,000 
routes daily. So basically, a quantum computer

could solve all those route problems and save 
the company a lot of money. And of course,

this space is only starting out. I'm going 
to refer to this report by McKinsey. It's an

excellent one throughout today's presentation. And 
this first slide shows how, in the current year,

the total amount of revenue generated from quantum 
computing is going to be about a billion dollars.

So, let's say IonQ has $110 million this year in 
revenues. What they're roughly expecting, well,

that would give them about 11% market share. And 
there are all these grandiose estimates of how

much potential market share there is to capture. 
They seem credible. Though quantum computing,

to be fair, has always been 5 years away for as 
long as I can remember. Now, we first looked at

IonQ about four years ago. We had favorable things 
to say about the company. We found the founders to

be quite accomplished. That usually means they'll 
be able to attract the best talent in that space.

They expected to deliver a rack-mounted quantum 
computer by 2023. Talk of the world's most

powerful quantum computer. And we said that 
we only wanted to see progress in the form of

revenue growth. Well, perhaps we spoke a bit too 
soon because not all types of revenue growth are

created equal. When we look at where the founders 
are today, they seem to have bailed for a career

in Academia. And in February of this year, you 
saw the CEO and CFO change. That's not good.

and the gentleman who stepped in as CEO at that 
time is now the Chairman of the Board. And when

you have a CEO who is also the chairman of 
the board, that's a conflict of interest,

it's frowned upon by those who assess governance 
in corporations. But there are really two

interpretations to be had here. The first would be 
that the old management team sucked, so they were

shown the door. That's because they missed their 
spack deck target so badly. And of course, the new

management team is going to make everything right. 
Or you might say that the founders bailed because

they didn't see the promise in the company, at 
least the core product offering that they were

showcasing at the time they had their SPAC. And 
all this management churn that we see indicates

a poorly company as typically is the case. Just 
today, actually, they lost their Chief Revenue

Officer. Who knows why? So let's just move past 
that and start looking at revenue growth. So, of

course, their glossy spack deck made promises they 
couldn't keep. They were expecting $237 million

for this year. They're now expecting instead about 
$108 million at the midpoint of guidance. Now,

this still represents very strong revenue growth. 
And we'd ask, well, where is that coming from? Is

this revenue coming from their core platform, 
the one that they showcased in their SPAC, or

is it coming from a lot of acquisitions that the 
company has been making lately? Well, the answer,

of course, is acquisitions during 2025. They made 
five different acquisitions. And it's so apparent

here in the balance sheet. Just look at the sharp 
increase in intangible assets and goodwill. So

basically, goodwill is when you go to acquire a 
company and you can't account for all the money

that you're paying for what you're receiving. 
So you simply put that in a bucket and say, "Oh,

that's goodwill." That's future value. We're going 
to realize later because this is such a great

acquisition. What it typically means is that you 
overpaid. Now, they're going to argue that they

overpaid for good reason. And the explanation 
for that comes from this diagram that McKinsey

put forth that shows how Quantum technology is 
really three major components. You have Quantum

Computing, what we're all familiar with. Then you 
have Quantum Communication and Quantum Sensing.

And when you move to IonQ's slide in their 
recent investor deck, you see here they describe

themselves as the only quantum platform company 
in the world. And they're touching on all these

areas, right? And that sort of makes sense when 
you look at who they acquired. So they acquired

a company called ID Quantique. We covered them 
I think it was six years ago and looked at their

hardware and they dabbled in Quantum Security 
and Quantum Communication Services. So it would

make sense that IonQ would acquire them to fill 
those gaps in their offering. And here you can

see a list of the acquisitions that were made in 
2025. It appears to be six different names. And

I wanted to focus on three of these. So we talked 
about ID Quantique. You can check our past piece

to learn more about what they do. Then we have 
Oxford Ionics. So they're dabbling in trapped

ion technology, which is what ion dabbles in. 
And, of course, the easy-to-understand thesis

would be that they've simply acquired a competitor 
so they can accelerate their development efforts.

And that's particularly important because they 
have a very formidable competitor. We're going

to talk about a little bit later. And then there 
was the acquisition that I really had to take a

second look at because it didn't really seem 
to make sense. So Capella Space and, of course,

the story is that Capella's technology will 
be used as a basis for their Quantum Space

hardware. They're ultimately going to sell to 
other satcom firms, right? And their executive

chairman at the time makes this statement. He 
says, "Capella has an application today which

is revenue generating." Yeah, it's generating 
revenues, but these aren't quantum revenues.

their plan for turning this into a quantum play 
comes down the road. He goes on to talk about a

platform with bulletproof space heritage. Yeah, 
remember that. So, I guess the question here is

how much revenue are we talking about? Because if 
it's a lot, then the pure playness, if you will,

of IonQ just dropped meaningfully. And we can turn 
to this firm called LatkaAI. They talk about how

Capella Space hit $74 million in revenue in 
2023. Well, that would be roughly 70% of the

revenues that IonQ is guiding for this year. But, 
of course, that number was back in 2023. And when

you look at this comment made in an earnings call 
by IonQ, they talk about how they're now going to

own and operate a proliferated constellation 
of low Earth orbit satellites that they plan

to outfit with quantum stuff. Well, when you 
continue reading this article by Payload,

it's rather telling. So, in 2023, the same year 
they had the supposed $73 million in revenues,

the company suffered propulsion problems that 
led its satellites to decay faster than expected.

Apparently, the founding CEO stepped down that 
fall. And in this story, they talk about how the

number of Capella spacecraft in orbit right now 
would be four following two deorbits in March and

May of 2025. So, there's a really good question 
to ask here. What has IonQ actually purchased? If

they purchased $73 million in revenues, they just 
diluted their quantum exposure a lot. They're now

dabbling in something very different from the 
quantum work, the core quantum work that we

all signed up for in that SPAC deck. And if they 
didn't, if the revenues fell dramatically because

half the satellites fell out of the sky, we're 
falling right out of the sky. Then it sounds like

they purchased a failed business. Which is it? 
This just sounds like a typical SPAC playbook,

right? You raise a bunch of money by making 
grandiose promises that you realize you can't

keep. Then you take your cash windfall and start 
buying companies with it. You're bolting on that

revenue growth. And exactly what sort of bargains 
are you hoping to acquire when you're operating

during a time when there's a lot of quantum hype. 
Investors who are selling their quantum companies

are going to want a premium, which is why we see 
such a large goodwill balance on their balance

sheet. Rarely does this strategy work out as 
planned. And for those of you that think it will,

you're going to pay a pretty price to participate. 
So, before I start talking about valuation,

I wanted to address a question that we've been 
getting a lot lately about the elephant in the

room. Why have I been shooting videos from an 
ancient temple in the Japanese mountains? Okay,

nobody asked. I just wanted to talk about it. So, 
as you might know, our Romanian fortune teller

recently submitted her resignation letter, which 
means we're scrambling to find alternative sources

of alpha. One possible source, you guessed 
it, Buddhism. And the population of Japan is

declining. So, you get more karma for your dollar. 
So, I'd like to extend a big Arigato Gozaimas to

every premium subscriber who recently participated 
in our customer focus survey. We're going to be

debuting a very cool enhancement soon, so stay 
tuned for that. Anywho, back to talking about

IonQ. So, when we look at the current valuation 
of this company, it's somewhere around $15

billion. We can then use a price-to-sales ratio 
because these companies don't have profit. So,

you can't use your typical price-to-earnings 
ratio, right? So, we have expected sales for 2025

of $108 million and we'll just use that number, 
and we get a value of 137. So we need something

to benchmark that against. I've pulled up our 
tech stock catalog here and I simply filtered

on the companies with the highest what we call 
simple valuation ratio. So we take market cap and

divide it by annualized revenues, not forecasted 
revenues. And here you can see that, what we call,

the simple valuation ratio or SVR. You can see 
that calculated along with their average over

the past year. And then we have a premium or a 
discount. Kind of cool, right? So you can see well

Robinhood has just gone through the roof in terms 
of their valuation. Same thing for Rocket Lab and,

of course, Palantir. Now, if you took the average 
of all the companies that we calculate this for,

it's somewhere around 7.5. Our cutoff is 
three times that. So let's say around 22. We

just don't buy companies that are richer than 
that. And compared to these other companies,

IonQ is extremely overvalued. So what 
you can then do, this is rather fun,

is you can back out the share price based on what 
sorts of valuations it ought to trade at. So let's

say it traded at the same valuation Palantir did, 
well that would be about $31 a share. If it traded

at the same valuation as Rocket Lab, that would 
be $14 a share. And if it traded at our cutoff,

roughly around 22, that would be just under $7 
a share. So this firm is extremely overvalued

and even IonQ agrees. You go back to their SPAC 
deck, when they're talking about valuation here,

they use a 10 times to 15 times revenue multiple. 
They knew not to use a 100 times revenue multiple

because even Joe Retail, well maybe not DGen Joe 
Retail, but even a retail investor with a small

amount of investing acumen would realize that's 
absolutely ridiculous. And here you can see their

ridiculous valuation over time. We've plotted this 
over about a year and a half. You can see how it

went from floating around the 30s to, sort of, 
getting up there close to 200. But right now it's,

as I said, floating around the mid-130s mark. 
So what we usually say to investors is if you're

going to set a valuation target, you should always 
have one. If you're dabbling in the volatile world

of tech stocks, what you can do is take the last 
four values, average them, and set that as your

target. Well, that's not going to work so well 
here, right? Because this is persistently traded

at such a rich valuation for such a long period 
of time. Two things will happen. Fundamentals

will catch up or the valuation will revert to the 
mean. This isn't controversial. This is simply

how markets work. You have to be careful about a 
lot of the flowery language they use. Of course,

here they're talking about delivering the 
world's most powerful quantum computer. I

thought they already had that. Maybe it's this 
special one with 2 million cubits by 2030. Folks,

it's always five years away, right? Well, maybe 
this time it's different. Could very well be,

with all the money being poured into quantum 
computing. But one expert I spoke with said

that when companies start talking about cubits, 
that's like a car being advertised with a price

tag where you can't see what the mileage is, 
right? So without key additional information,

that means next to nothing. I think Joe Retail 
has a tendency to think that quantum computing

is simply the four stonks that he sees shooting 
to the moon every day. But you see here IBM's

press release this past summer. They expect to 
debut the first largecale fault tolerant. That's

very important for anybody that understands the 
problems that they're facing in this space. The

first fault-tolerant quantum computer. It's 
projected to run 20,000 times more operations

than today's quantum computers. The one thing 
noticeable here is the approach they're taking

where they use logical cubits which are built 
on top of physical cubits, and that's supposed

to solve the error correction problems. And you 
see other firms are taking this approach as well,

from the McKinsey report. Some of the world's 
biggest tech companies are dabbling here. You've

got Google, Amazon, Microsoft, right? IBM. And 
this next slide is very nice. It breaks down

the approaches taken by various companies. And 
look here to the right. You have trapped ions.

There's IonQ. There's another company called AQT. 
I think they're out of Switzerland and Continuum.

So that's the Honeywell spin-off. That's one you 
should really be watching closely. And then you

go over here through the left and then you can see 
the other various approaches being taken. But when

you look at funding, and there's a lot of it going 
into quantum startups. And this chart, of course,

taken from the McKinsey report needs to be updated 
with this little factoid. So, Continuum has now a

valuation of $10 billion following a $600 million 
raise they did just several months ago. That

doubled their valuation from the $5 billion it 
was earlier last year. And, of course, NVIDIA's

invested. Well, what isn't NVIDIA invested in? 
Doesn't mean a whole lot, right? They have so much

cash. But some of these other names are notable. 
Of course, Honeywell, you have JP Morgan, Chase,

and Mitsui. So it's likely that these investors 
see something very promising with Continuum which

is a direct competitor to IonQ. So let's sort 
of ignore statements that IonQ says here. I

noted one in particular. "We can confidently state 
that in almost every case beyond IonQ, it's just

a branding attempt." Really? So all 270 quantum 
computing startups out there, they're all branding

attempts, right? None of them are doing anything 
legitimate? Certainly, it's a red flag when you

have C-suite types saying ridiculous things, and 
IonQ seems to be saying no shortage of ridiculous

things. Though, of course, the bull thesis that 
they're proposing, right, is compelling on paper,

and they now have a whole bunch of cash. So this 
year they raised, I guess, $3 billion. They have

$3.5 billion in their balance sheet now. And when 
they talk about what they're going to use it for

now, they talk about investing in R&D. Well, 
they've spent an awful lot of money on R&D. I

think $200 million for the first 9 months of this 
year. What exactly are they building if they're

having to acquire everything? Let's say, well, 
we're integrating everything together. Okay. So,

once you get done with all these purchases, what's 
the growth rate going to look like then? That's

very key piece of information. Well, what might 
happen here is they're going to take this $3.5

billion and they're just going to keep acquiring, 
right? It's not necessarily a good thing at all.

So nearly every response that's going to be 
critical of our analysis will have some sort of

FOMO variation to it. This time it's different in 
reference to the valuation. No, it's not. There is

no rush at all here. And I like this table here. 
So what do Space Nuclear and Quantum Computing

stocks have in common? Well, the answer is DGEN. 
So all of the stocks that you see here on this

list are overvalued and being hyped very heavily. 
And look how they move in unison. There almost

seems to be a sort of correlation happening here. 
And that correlation, of course, is DGEN behavior.

Be very careful out there. So we're going to check 
back in a year to see if the valuation is more

reasonable and if these acquisitions have stopped. 
So then we can get an idea of what this collective

company looks like going forward and what sort of 
guidance they're giving on this new grand platform

that they've built. And in the meantime, other 
companies might see all this money being thrown

at publicly traded Quantum firms and want to get 
in on the action. And of course, that's happening.

There's a new Quantum Computing IPO that's 
coming. We analyzed that for you in this recent

piece. Give that a watch next. Thanks so much 
for taking the time to watch this video today.
